title: Transformers Titans Return Leader Soundwave Rifle v4
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a rifle for "Transformers Titans Return Leader Class Soundwave".

I think it kind of sucks that this guy is missing his signature "Concussion Rifle" that almost every other version of Soundwave includes in some form. So I made this in tinkerCAD.

It has an extended mode for use as a rifle as well as a compact "battery" mode for storage on Soundwave's back.

I printed with supports on but you may not need them.

I printed in white pla and gave the model an initial coat of blue (with a sharpie) so that there is no white visible through the slide gaps.
Then assembled with superglue, sanded painted and sealed.

I did find that the blaster tip slides in a little too far making it hard to pull back out. I ended up just gluing a small piece of plastic inside before assembly that limited the distance that the barrel tip can retract.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4BisYGTf4IT

title: Full-Height Raspberry Pi Sleeve Case with CSI, DSI, & GPIO Holes

description.text:
This is a remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1015706 to add holes for DSI, CSI, and GPIO connectors as well as to add some internal clearance to better fit Raspberry Pi 2's and 3's.

This case is "full-height" compared a "slim" case. The top of the case is flush with the the USB and Ethernet jacks.

Note that this case is still friction fit, so you may have to use a bit of force to get your Pi inside. To get your Pi back out, you can push on the board through the holes that let the power and activity LEDs shine through.

Thanks to dktosoch for providing editable STEP files.

Onshape link (exportable): https://cad.onshape.com/documents/0527f85374c3470f163b524c/w/44ee3ce6fee61d0f2862f97d/e/0fcbe309e023cd8c8b6efd02

description.text:
I offered a surface nesting drain strainer that had some negatives. So, I came up with this one that solved those problems. But, it may or may not fit your drain. You may have to modify the overall diameter, which should be pretty easy to do depending on your 3D STL creation program.

The basic problem is one I have noticed with even commercial surface nesting drain strainers. They have a perpetual wet area which is due to water caught between the under side of the strainer and the surface of the sink. This is a perfect breeding ground for bacterial growth, which manifested itself with my first strainer. So, I improved it by designing the strainer to sit down in the sink drain itself. The holes are calculated for easily draining away maximum flow from my faucet, which is about 1.5 gallons/minute (~ 5.7 liters/min). But, you may notice the middle hole is a bit larger. It is that way to fit my finger for lifting it out. So far, about 70 days of use and no smell, no bacteria and has held up nicely even with boiling water from pasta drained through it. The "cup" shape (which faces down into the drain to rest on the inside ledge present in most drains) is set to have the surface of the strainer level with the surface of the bottom of my sink. Your sink design may vary. If you need help making adjustments, just PM me with a request and I can redesign it for your sink drain specification- depth and diameter, inches or mm is fine. (No charge). But, this drain strainer works great, is simple and is very easy to keep clean and to use. I eliminated the tiny holes and slots as my first design had, that was too hard to clean.

title: Tronxy X3 Supercooler - hot end fan shrouds
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE: Check out this Mitten Cooler newer design I just released. Should work well and need only a 5015 fan.

My stock built Tronxy X3 printer's hot end could not go above 205ºC. The stock design cools the heater block too much. I wanted to printer higher temp >220ºC filaments and could not with the stock printer. So here is my solution.

It reuses the screws from the hot end radiator, but they only work if you remove the washers.

It's designed for left and right 30x30x10mm fans (12v) but you could get by with just one. If you add the left one, then you need to use my custom x stop.
Custom x Endstop: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1906501

Wire the 30mm fans in parallel -- and added my own y-connector.

If this is helpful, a tip would be nice. At least a like and show your makes.

Assembly video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aMM67JGe3qQ

Please note, this is not compatible with the auto leveling sensor. If I get enough requests, I may figure something out. ;)

Printer:

Tronxy X3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15-0.25mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

3 shells or outlines.

Print one in PLA and then use it to get to higher temps and then reprint in ABS, ASA, or PETG.

The heating element wires get warm and will warp a PLA version, but so far, my ABS shows no issues after many hours of printing.

Don't over-tighten the screws mounting the fans or you risk stripping the screw holes o the shrouds.
For PETG, I've been running the part cooling fans at 25% and they seem to work well.

As usual, my gateway drug of choice is Onshape.

I started the design on my iPad and then switched to my desktop since I have a bit finer control with my mouse and a bit faster--but not as comfy as designing on the couch with my dog at my side.

Untested design, please report any issues! A holder for a single button cell. It can be adjusted to almost any battery, or multiple cells if you add the height of the cells. Usage: Print and stick two pieces of wire through the holes in the sides. Slide in the button cell. If the fit is too tight, modify the parameters, starting with tolerance. Likewise if the fit is too loose, set tolerance to a smaller value. Example files: CR1225 cell holder:
diameter=12mm
height=2.5mm
tolerance=0.5mm
wall thickness=2mm CR2032 cell holder:
diameter=20mm
height=3.2mm
tolerance=0.5mm
wall thickness=2mm

description.text: I remixed the MK9 Bowden extruder from kharar to fit the Geeetech MK8 extruder that came on the Geeetech aluminum Prusa printer I am working on. I must say that I have worked on the MK8 for weeks and had no luck getting it to stop jamming, so I converted it to a Bowden using a E3Dv6 head. The Geeetech MK8 has a strange looking bottom on the plastic part of the extruder that was different than the other adapters I have seen, so I drew up one so other people can change theirs to a Bowden as well. It is made to fit on top of the printer which is 6mm thick aluminum. It has a hole to screw in a Bowden tube adapter with 6mm threads.

Raspberry Pi 3 case in a nice cute retro look package.
This very stylish design by http://www.thingiverse.com/McNugget is intended to be laser-cut, but I adapted it for 3D printing. Your mileage may vary.

FROM McNUgget's instructions:
Please put in the back plate first and then use 1\4" nylon stand-offs for mounting the raspberry pi 3 to the base place.
Use two nylon nuts in the base plate and 12mm nylon screws to close the case.

Be aware that the Raspberry Pi 3 DOES NOT have 3mm holes for mounting. The person who came up with this needs to be ... tickled for a very long time!
I drilled mine (yes, that means drilling out the holes in the pi board) to 1/8" to make my four nylon screws fit.

This thing is an S-clip for attaching gap filler "pillows" to a winter pool cover such as a loop-loc or jersey cover. Originally my cover came with a few random stainless steel clips and plastic clips, neither of which worked very well and allowed the pillows to flop around and eventually detach from the cover. This clip is thicker and stronger and has an improved barb design so it snaps crisply onto the cover and holds it in place. I printed some in ABS (black) and the rest in hi-performance PLA (blue) to see which material fares best in the elements.

title: Surfing Styled Hook to Hang a Hat or Sweater

description.text:
I created this cool solution to hang my hat/hats from my closet door. Also, it can hang sweatshirts, belts or whatever you want within reason. You can decide how many links you want to print depending on how far you want it to hang down.

Update- My door is 34mm wide, if yours is different you can try scaling the part door_clip, or I would be happy to upload alternate versions to fit different width doors (comment or message me with a specific dimension).

Resolution:

.22

Infill:

24%

Notes:

You have two orientation choices for printing the parts as shown in the pictures, I choose to print mine using the first option, but if you want to hang heavier things use option 2 along with increasing the number of perimeters in your slicing setting.

After printing to assemble use pieces of raw 1.75 mm filament to create the pins for the hinges. You can glue the pieces in, or use a hot object (hot glue gun or your extruder on low heat) to mushroom the ends of the pieces so that they wont fall out.
Also, I wrapped some string around the top of the hook piece.

-If the holes need cleaning up to work use a 5/64'' drill bit.

print_settings.Notes:: 2 shell walls.

description.text:
Took over 55 photos of the ceramic swallow, then uploaded it into Autodesk ReMake. Modified and trimmed the mesh, then exported it as an STL. Imported the STL into Netfabb to repair the STL, and also turn the shell into a 3D solid. Then exported the STL again. Then I 3D printed it.

Interestingly, ReMake worked on this in mm, needed to scale 1000% in Netfabb to size as cm. STL attached should be in cm - about 15 x 16 cm.

Printer:

3D Stuffmaker Prusa Explorer

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

10%

Notes:

The STL file is 50% flat, the other 50% is one layer off the bed. Needs supports to print as is, or use tools to push the design .5mm into the print bed.

2 shell walls.

Uploaded photos in ReMake with ultra mesh and converted in the cloud.
Trimmed away the supporting desk and used the fix tool to repair the mesh.

Mesh RCM file has been uploaded, if you would like to edit it yourselves.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed these in PLA for prototype use only with the intention of printing the final pieces in ABS but after using them in PLA I have had zero warping/melting on any of them. I even had a 35 hour print with no issues.

description.text:
This is a remix of Josef's fan duct for the Mk2. I wanted something that better surrounded the nozzle to achieve finer detail on all sides of parts. It seems to have excellent air flow and it blows down on the part and not at the nozzle. It fits my machine perfectly hopefully it will fit yours as well. The file with "draft angle" is referring to the bottom of the duct facing the bed. I had been using a Micro Swiss nozzle, not an E3D nozzle and they are longer but I did not realize this when I initially designed it. This file was modified at the request of someone having clearance issues to the bed. Enjoy!

Update 12/29/2016
Added 3rd & 4th files. The 3rd file is a more complete circle around the nozzle and has tremendous airflow in all directions. The 4th file is a complete circle around the nozzle. It's airflow doesn't seem to be as good as the 3rd file but give it a go if you like.

Update 12/18/2016
Added second file with center flap.

Update
Adjusted model with a slight draft angle to the bottom for better clearance.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed these in PLA for prototype use only with the intention of printing the final pieces in ABS but after using them in PLA I have had zero warping/melting on any of them. I even had a 35 hour print with no issues.

description.text:
Finally here it is: the â€œVersion Zeroâ€ of a printed paper windmill. One day I would like to upload another version (you can see it in one of the pictures) but, while it woks, the wings still have too much issues... we'll see.
This thing, as provided here requires little wind to start its movement and very little wind to keep on  spinning. It's not made to be efficient but just a toy. Do use the OpenSCAD (good luck) to make it bigger, better, nicer!
There are some pictures here: flickr.com/photos/aubenc/sets/72157629199542154/
And (not that) a short video here: youtube.com/watch?v=cjXmF2cNxVg

I wrote a lot (my apologies) in the PDF so I'll keep it short here.
Print in 3 different colors, assemble and have fun!
The zip file contains more STL for wings with different thicknesses and threaded parts with different tolerances.
Think it twice before deciding to use the producion plates! bot1334 required different setting for the wings and the threads.
(sorry but it has to be said...)
Be aware that this thing can spin really fast and thus can produce damages or hurt somebody whenever it breaks, something gets loose or not. I take no responsibility if something goes wrong.

title: The 3D Printed Marble Machine by Maher Soft
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a 3D Printed marble machine on our latest Indie 3D Printer that takes marbles through crazy loops and turns. A marble machine designed in ONSHAPE is completely based on rigid bodies, rigid body joints and mechanics. The assembly has approximately 34 parts printed in ABS , and it can be powered by using DC motors or batteries. It uses a 1.5 cm diameter steel marble, which starts at the bottom, and goes to the top, and then returns to the bottom, making this trip about 8640 times in 24 hours.

Indie on Indiegogo - https://youtu.be/e9V8IUPSevg

Marble Machine Video -
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PAynwHogPto&feature=youtu.be

Sign up now to buy Indie on Indiegogo at $549 - http://www.mahersoft.com/indie
(Only for Early Bird Backers)
The new 3D printed marble machine we have all been waiting for!

Follow us on
Facebook - www.facebook.com/mahersoft3d
Twitter - www.twitter.com/mahersoft3d
Instagram - www.instagram.com/mahersoft3d
Website - www.mahersoft.com
Contact - [email protected]

Made one yourself? Feel free to upload your photos
Inspiraion: Daniel Parker

Printer:

Indie: The Desktop 3D Printer

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 micron

Infill:

15-20%

Notes:

We have attached the instruction document along with spare list and drawing for rod. Please refer the documentation.
NO SUPPORTS NEEDED!
Some parts might not fit on a small print bed, we recommend you to cut the file in 2 parts and glue later.
15- 25% Infill worked best for me.
0.2 mm layer height.
Try out the best settings for yourself.
Steel ball bearings
Go3d
Printed on Indie 3D Printer

Designing

At first glance, it may look relatively simple, but a lot of planning and tweaking had to go into the design process keeping in mind that all parts have to be 3D Printed and support free to avoid any kind of post processing. It took us approximately 2-3 weeks to design the assembly on Onshape and a series of iterations to make a working model of the marble machine.

The whole assembly consists of 34 3D Printed parts, nuts, screws, and a DC motor to provide a rotary mechanism.
The marble starts at the bottom, and goes to the top, and then returns to the bottom, making this trip about 8640 times in 24 hours. Each step lifts the marble back up to the top of the slide in a synchronous manner. Here, the entire process starts all over again and continues so long as you keep turning the CAM shaft.

description.text:
A straight key that could be used for portable operation. I made 2 versions. One works without bearings and that works pretty smooth, with a little sanding the parts that fit together. The 2nd version needs 2 ball bearings 3x10x4. Those worked great for me: http://eu.banggood.com/Wholesale-Warehouse-10pcs-623-ZZ-3x10x4mm-Deep-Groove-Ball-Bearings-Miniature-Bearings-wp-Eu-81182.html
The lever is designed to have a 3.5mm gold contact bullet connectors fitted in that is used as 1 of the 2 contacts. Something like that: https://hobbyking.com/en_us/polymax-3-5mm-gold-connectors-10-pairs-20pc.html. You can use male or female. Does not matter.
The counterpart is a contact broken out of of a Deans T-plug, like that one https://hobbyking.com/en_us/nylon-t-connectors-male-10pcs-bag.html
You can also use something different that fits into the slot a made for easier positioning.
As socket for the cable I use a 3.5mm socket. I bought mine from Amazon. https://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B008SO06TU
Not the best quality, but works. I shortened the 2 pins that go to the gnd and the middle section of the plug, so that my youkits HB1B identifies it as a straight key.
I glued everything in place with hot glue.
Will upload fotos of the parts needed and the built after I built my next key. Do not have any here that is not allready glued together.
I do not use spings but use neodyme magnets. For the screw I use 2pcs. 5x2 and for the lever I use 2 pcs. 8x2mm. Tension can be adjusted using the screw to bring the magnets closer together or further away.
Magnets
http://www.banggood.com/20pcs-N40-D8x2mm-Neodymium-Magnets-Rare-Earth-Strong-Magnet-p-972806.html
http://www.banggood.com/30pcs-D5x2mm-N35-Neodymium-Magnets-Rare-Earth-Strong-Magnet-p-981726.html
You also need a bolt M3 22mm and a nut M3 to assemble it.

On request I can upload a step file or something elxe I can export from Fusion360. So you can make some changes to dimensions.

Printer:

Flashforge creator pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

case, base lever 20%, screws 100%

Notes:

Case has to be flipped 180° to print.
screws best printed ad higher resolution, but 0.2 works too. screws with 100% infill. The rest with 20%.

title: Realacc X210  flexible 45° vtx antenna mount

description.text:
Sturdy bracket for mounting a video transmitter pigtail 45 degrees out the rear of the quad without using the extra carbon plate. Best printed solid in TPU. This version includes slots which line up with the ones in the top plate allowing for a small zip tie to be used to hold it against the top plate. I've found it to protect the antenna and SMA connector very well in crashes or upside down landings, the TPU flexes and takes the strain but is extremely tough and resistant to tearing along layer planes.

Update June 10 2017: added 60 degree and 30 degree options for the mount! and a step file of the original to make it easier to mod if you like.

title: Realacc X210 stack offset and X4R mount

description.text: I like the x210 frame but it bothered me that the camera doesn't clear the flight controller stack when it is tilted to be level. This offsetter plate moves the entire stack toward the rear of the quad by several millimeters, which gives the camera enough clearance for any angle. It also provides a neat place to mount an X4R-SB between the pdb and the flight controller. Combine with my rx and vtx antenna mounts, and a stackable mount for the vtx of your choice, and you can make a very compact build. The ET200 mount is what I used, when modified to replace the SMA with a pigtail and mounted with the output facing forward, the band/channel LEDs are easily visible in the top plate cutout, and button accessible from the side.

comments.text: What print settings did you use?  Any supports?
comments.author: DeaBow

comments.text: Print solid, I usually set top or bottom solid layers to a value thicker than the part instead of entering 100% infill. Print oriented as shown in the pic (right side up) over closely spaced "line" type supports. I usually set the gap between part and supports to zero and just spend a minute scraping/cutting them off the part afterwards.
comments.author: DeaBow

comments.text:
Here is a suggestion for a revision: enlarge the base of the top standoffs a bit, and model a hex-shaped recess on their underside. This would allow the user to glue an M3 nut under the offset plate, for easier intervention on the stack above.
(This is assuming that a 3D printer wouldn't be able to produce a proper threading of the holes, which would ofc be a much nicer solution).
comments.author: khrab

comments.text:
I considered using a captured nut like you describe, but decided to keep it simple :)
printing threads at 0.5mm pitch isn't possible on my machine, but I could print the hole in a diameter such that screwing it in basically taps it at the same time.
Another even better option would be some heat-set thermoplastic inserts, they're M3 threaded and install into a predefined hole size using a soldering iron. They're knurled and slightly barbed so after the plastic melts around them they lock into place very strongly. Would add a little weight though.
In any case this thing is solidly built into the quad now and i don't plan on changing it unless it breaks and I have to print another anyway. I can upload the source files though if you (or anyone) would like to edit them, however.
comments.author: khrab

comments.text: Thanks for the idea, I didn't know about these inserts. In any case, the source files would be great - I'd love to be able to remix this to make it compatible with a LemonRX satellite receiver.
comments.author: earlynerd

comments.text:
OK I uploaded the .sldprt file, I can export in a different format after work today if you need. Also I'm a 3d CAD noob so I've probably gone about drawing it in a weird or backwards way somehow, but I manage to get it done usually. Good luck editing it though...
These are the inserts I was talking about, extremely useful for making strong 3d printed parts, especially where they need to be screwed together tightly or where they may need to be assembled/disassembled multiple times where plastic threads would wear out. Both are m3, I expect that the shorter one would work best for this.
https://www.mcmaster.com/#94180a331/=155l9k6
https://www.mcmaster.com/#94180a333/=155l9q2

My Dad dug out an old wooden train set circa 1972 for the grandkids to play with but found the chimney that served as the wind up key had broken. He called me to ask about what glue I would try after failing with several types himself.  I told him to mail the whole train engine and broken key down and I'd either design and print a new one or find a way to fix the original.  I spent some time with OpenSCAD and a half dozen test prints later, a replacement was made. Printing a few spares to go back with it.  
The perfect color would be to use Makerbot's standard red ABS and then give it an acetone vapor bath which makes it turn the same orange color as the rest of the train parts (I have another print I did this to and the colors match) but I only have their fluorescent red ABS which I don't think will fade the same.

title: CloudOver.io Raspberry PI case with Blender sources

description.text:
Raspberry PI case by CloudOver.io

This case was designed for CoreCluster Cloud Starter Kit. Works with Raspberry PI model 3B. It was inspired by Raspberry Pi 3, Pi 2, and Model B+ case with VESA mounts and more, however it has no VESA mounts and it is recreated from the beginning.

Source model and modifications

Feel free to reuse it and create new, based on it cases. Change with your logo, add texts or new holes for wires. Find attahed Blender model with all necessary to create objects:

  • Layer 1 - Bare case shape without any holes with all boolean modifiers. Use them to generate final objects
  • Layer 2 - models with applied all modificators, ready to export to STL, with CloudOver.io logo
  • Layer 3 - all objects used to cut the holes and mounts with boolean modifiers

In edit mode you should see, that Layer 1 objects are in fact just shells. Use or modify objects in layer 3 to adjust shapes, holes and other parts of this cases in Layer 1. To create new holes or add some parts, create new Boolean modifiers in Difference or Union mode and select new object to add or remove from the shells.

Remember, that shells should be placed exactly in the place, where they are in the Layer 1! Moving them will cause mismatch with the boolean modifiers and objects from Layer 3!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 by Geeetech

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Use Slic3r to convert from .stl to .gcode files. The Octaspiral Top/bottom fill pattern gives nice pattern results with top and bottom parts of this case.

Blender

This model is Open Source. Please, feel free to adjust it to your own. Use Blender (from blender.org) to adjust your model of case. You can easly change logo to your own, or add some texts.

TIP 1: Remember, to apply all boolean modifiers on object before converting to STL and select "Export only selected" in export window.

TIP 2: Sometimes Blender has problems with exporting proper models (there are some open walls). Use Ctrl+N in edit mode, on all Vertices (Ctrl+A) to make all Normals consistent. It this fails, use Remesh modifier on final object.

title: Fume Extractor - 120mm Fan Shroud & Duct Adaptor

description.text:
This is a soldering fume extractor designed for a 12v 120mm case fan & can be used with or without the flexible tube (pictured). It's designed to mount onto a lamp arm but could be mounted onto any base.  
The duct adapter reduces from 120mm to 85mm diameter sleeve to suit the flexible downpipe available from Bunnings in Australia for $9.90 AUD.

Printing:
Duct & Shroud: Infill 20%
Layer Height 0.2mm
Number of shells 2
Feedrate 90 mm/s
Travel Feedrate 150 mm/s
Print Temperature 230c This was printed with black 1.75mm PLA on mbot Rep2. Assembly:
1) Bolt the duct to the mount with a 3/16" countersunk bolt with a wingnut & rubber washer.
2) Bolt the Shroud & Duct to the Fan with 4x 3/16" countersunk bolts.
3) Cut off the standard rectangular connections of flexible downpipe hose with an x-acto knife to leave the tapered round end.
4) Slip the flexible hose into the 85mm diameter duct connection. Enjoy!

description.text:
My latest tankbot has been designed to be a larger vehicle but printable on a small scale printer.

https://youtu.be/KUup3ndVikM

A number of issues with the other tanks have been overcome (hopefully) with this one.

UPDATE 1: Have modified COG - Please use V4 to overcome track catch issue. The catch issue is far more evident when printed in PLA than ABS.

UPDATE 2: Added two new track variations. These allow for variations in materials, print settings and printer type. I find that my printer and ABS tends to work OK on the standard track, while my printer and PLA needs a combination of the 2.2 and 2.4 track types. The number refers to the centre diameter of the pin hole. The idea is to maintain enough tension in the track, while simultaneously allowing free movement

First and foremost it now runs on two standard sized continuous rotation servos. You can obtain these with various torque settings to suit your needs!

Secondly the tracks are specifically designed to be joined with 1.75mm filament offcuts. These save the need to order expensive stainless steel rods and because they flex, they hold themselves in without need for glue.

Thirdly I have designed it to bolt together rather than being glued - so that changing parts - or reconfiguring it is now possible.

Notes and hints:

  • The tank should fit a range of standard sized servos (they are not all that "standard") but you may need to play around with the square spindle to fit your servo nicely into the cog.
  • I like to over power my robots in terms of battery (the one in the video has 12V), and then use a step down power converted to power the servos - this means that you get longer drive time, more power and less chance of your controller (Arduino in my case) resetting because the servos stole all of the juice.
  • I have designed a number of different body configurations. Feel free to play around with what ever suits your needs.
  • I have so far only designed an external Arduino Uno mount, but you could run it on any controller that suits.
  • I designed this specifically for my Up! Plus, but it developed a fault halfway through the design phase and I finished it on a ProJet full colour powder printer that I have access to. You can still print it in and FDM printer greater than 100mm x 100mm
  • The body section with the build in sensor is designed for a HC-SR04 untrasonic sensor and the Adafruit RGB Color Sensor.
    *The body section with the provision for the 12V battery clip (which takes 8 x AA batteries) also has provision for a 16mm round press switch.
  • You will need 26 tracks per side - note print the tracks without supports, otherwise the pin holes clog up and you need to drill them out. A 2mm drill bit does this nicely ;)

You can access the source files from here:
https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B0oR8i_t-zjyVnRWb1hxeUlPRlE

Printer Brand:

Up!

Printer:

Up Plus

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

The body parts can be tricky. I get best results printing them on their side, and then treat them with a very quick acetone vapour bath (not heated) to prevent splitting.

I also print the tracks WITHOUT SUPPORTS.

First version of OLED pressure meter case.

This is the Australian version of the trolley key, it imitates a $2 coin and fools the lock mechanism. It is fully retrievable (don't worry you won't lose it to the trolley). It has an easy to pull grip which will ensure the key is retrieved no matter what. All edges and points are curved so as not to prick you or make you feel uncomfortable.

The design is 2.8mm thick and roughly the size of a business card making it easy to store in a wallet or pocket.

Edit: Version two (v2) contains rounded edges and a more slim version of the 'coin' for easier retrieval. I have left version one in the files incase any would like it.

Edit: In version three (v3) the writing and labelling have been removed for a more subtle appearance due to popular demand in the comments section.

Note: If you would like a British pound version of the key note that the British pound coin is 1.1x larger than the Australian $2 coin so all that is necessary is a small scale adjustment.

This is a new version of an earlier published fan duct for 60 mm fan.

The cross section of this duct, is widened to give the 60 mm fan full justice.
The horisontal orientation of the fan, gives more space for the filament tubes and the cables.

The lid is glued to the main structure.
For the mounting clips, M3 screws and nuts can be used.
Personally I use more brutal self tapping screws.

Note that there are two diffrent files for the main duct.
One is for those who trust in the slicer program's self-generated support structure.
There is also an (rather ugly) optional file with support bars. (Of course to be cut off)
Wery useful thing for home. You can use it with drinking straws.

Prusa I3 Steel

No

0.4mm

20%

This gantry brace (i.e. table top leg) was made with Tinkercad and can edited or modified by simply visiting https://www.tinkercad.com/things/jFlSrot7DNI asthe is here was to create a gantry brace fro the TEVEO Tarantula DIY 3D Printer kit which didn't require the printer to be bolted or screwed to some surface as with other designs. Instead this simply mounts to the gantry uprights via an 8mm M5 bolt (link: http://amzn.to/2fKuhSS) and maker rail cleats (flat nuts link: http://amzn.to/2gd1jdc).

To learn more about this and our other prints, please visit http://www.DIY3DTech.com as well check out our YouTube Channel at http://YouTube.DIy3DTech.com to learn more about 3D Printing, CNC Machining, and CO2 Laser cutting & engraving! Also if you are looking for maker swag be sure to check out http://Swag.DIY3Dtech.com for one of a kind Maker Swag!

M5 8mm Length Low Profile Hex Socket Machine Screws (Pack of 100)
http://amzn.to/2fKuhSS

Pre-Assembly Square Nuts Flat M5 T Nut for 2020 Aluminum Extrusions Pack of 100
http://amzn.to/2gd1jdc

Build and Installation Notes: you will need to print two of these (left & right) side of the printer, insert the M5 bolts and loosely attach the cleat/square nut and slide on from the bottom of the printer. Than allow the printer to sit flat on the table and tighten with an Allen wrench.

Printer:

Just About Any

No

No

.3 or better you pick

Infill:

20 to 50%

Notes:

As this doesn't hold an weight (the printer sits on the maker rail) as this idea with the "brace" to help prevent the gantry from rocking or tipping by increasing the surface area which comes into contact with the the tables surface.

author: CallJoe

title: IKEA Bastig Cabinet Knob Leveling Tool

description.text:
We thought we would update our kitchen with new brushed aluminum Bastig knobs from IKEA.  Call me anal, but I went nuts trying to level the knobs so they looked right. Because the knob is a slightly rounded pyramid shape you can't find a reliable flat spot to place a level.  I made this little tool to slide snugly down around the knob while providing a large flat area to place a small level.  
Frustration all gone.  Enjoy!

https://youtu.be/XEXLeQUbBTU

This is a 6th grade project done in connection with a unit on weather. The students will design and print a spinning weather vane. The aim of the activity is for the students to become more proficient in 3D design using Tinkecad. Building weather tools is really more of an elementary science activity so this could work well for grades younger than 6.

Skills / Tools emphasized in this lesson

  • Using the shift key to resize without changing the proportions
  • Rotating shapes
  • Using the Adjust - Align tool to center objects

The project uses 4" bamboo skewers from the grocery store as the shaft of the spinner. They fit nicely into a 4 mm socket. If you use different size skewers you may have to adjust the size of the socket.
NGSS
Students will use Tinkercad to design a spinning weather vane.

Base - these are all the same, so you can print them ahead of time
  • Drag a cone onto the workplane
  • Enlarge so the base is 50 mm in diameter (if you use the shift key you can keep the base round).
  • Drag a cylinder onto the workplane and make it a Hole
  • Resize so the diameter of the cylinder is 4 mm and it is taller than the cone
  • Select the cone and cylinder and use the Adjust -> Align tool to center the cylinder on the cone.
  • Lift the cylinder 2 mm off the workplane so the hole doesn't go all the way through the cone
    • Arrow
  • Drag a box onto the workplane and resize to be 100 mm long (x), 10 mm wide (y), 6 mm high (z-direction).
  • Drag a roof onto the workplane and rotate it to point to the right
  • Resize the roof to be an isosceles triangle 16 mm long (x), 32 mm wide (Y), and 6 mm high (z)
  • Check that the roof is on the workplane, lift it up if it's not.
  • Duplicate the roof
  • Move one triangular roof piece to the front of the arrow and the other to the back of the arrow.
  • Group the box and roof pieces to complete the arrow
    • Atop the Arrow
    Students can customize their weather vane by adding a design of their choice atop the arrow. This can be done by using shapes and letters from Tinkercad, or by importing a silhouette in SVG format. The objects added should be flat and 6mm in height (z) to match the size of the arrow. They should be aligned so the center of mass will be above the center of the arrow so the arrow is not front or back heavy. Add Socket to Arrow
  • Drag a cylinder onto the work plane.
  • Make it a hole
  • Resize so the diameter is 4 mm and length is 40 mm
  • Rotate the cylinder so it is parallel to the work plane along the y-axis, perpendicular to the arrow
  • Use the Adjust - Align tool to center the cylinder on the arrow, it should be centered in the x, y, and z direction.
  • The cylinder should extend a hole up through the bottom of the arrow and into the shape above. Make sure it doesn't go all the way through. A hole about 35 mm long will work well. Much longer and the spinner will be touching the base, too short and it won't be stable.
Some 4" bamboo skewers from the supermarket. You can find them in various sizes, just check the fit before doing the project with the students.

A magazine loader for the CMMG 25-round .22LR magazines used with AR conversion kits. It aids in pushing down the loaded rounds just enough for the next round to be inserted under the feed lips.
Once the next round is inserted, you can raise the loader and push the new round back until it seats in the magazine properly. Wash, rinse, repeat until the magazine is full.

comments.text: hello, i made this but the walls are too thin and the corners and are too sharp. Even at a high fill density and 3 layers for walls, tops and bottom this loader starts to flex when loading the last 5-7 rounds. It is too flimsy to fight against the magazine spring. I was loading a 25 round CMMG magazine. I think the body of the model needs to be twice are thick and needs to have rounded edges. Also the depressor could be increased by about 0.5 mm diameter. Printed in PLA, 2.0 mm layers, 0.4 nozzle.

title: 28mm wargame tabletop pipe system for 3/4 inch PVC pipes

description.text:
This is a tabletop pipe system for wargaming.

Supports are a must!

These couplings and bends fit 3/4 inch PVC pipe. I've printed everything but the 4 way connector at this point and they all work well. Since the 4 way is a remix of the others, it will be fine.

They are not fancy, but they work well enough on the table.

I'm looking at a catwalk system that would connect between the pipe supports. I'll publish if or when I come up with something I like.

If you like these and have any suggestions or constructive criticism, please comment.

title: Resistor Storage / Sorter with Wall Mount

description.text:
stylesuxx used his Customizable Storage Box with Drawers to create this great Resistor Storage (Resistor Sorter) thing.

I wanted to screw a stack of resistor boxes to my shop's wall so I created a very, very simple wall mount. Please note that the mount's base plate is intentionally tilted upwards so the drawers will not slide out by themselves or when lightly bumped.

The *.skp file for SketchUp is included so you can easily apply changes.

PS A blog post about the 3D printed resistor storage box with wall mount with some additional pieces of information on printing, warping, labeling, and the wall mount.

author: zeropage

description.text: This is a simple 3D printed platter to hold the Adafruit Trinket, a power jack, and a wire strain relief. The STL file as well as the OpenSCAD source are available. Although this design has a 90-degree corner, that corner has a lot of strain-relief. The outside edges have quarter-circles. The inside corner edge is rounded, not sharp. More information at the blog post: http://netninja.com/2013/11/16/introducing-the-trinket-platter/ OpenSCAD source is committed to the GitHub project page: https://github.com/BrianEnigma/trinket-platter

Print it as-is. You probably want a more dense infill than your printer default. Hardware you will have to supply:
  • An Adafruit Trinket
  • A panel-mount power jack. Mine was a standard Arduino 2.1mm jack. Unfortunately, I can't tell you where to get one exactly like mine. It was in my parts bin, possibly from Radio Shack, possibly from Digikey. The through-hole threaded portion has a 7.6mm outside diameter. The panel hole is just a bit larger than that. If you need to adjust the hole size, it's easy to find the value in the OpenSCAD source file.
  • M2 screws and nuts to attach the Trinket. Both the screws and nuts I used were from McMaster-Carr.
  • A zip-tie to hold and act as strain-relief for any wires going to and from the Trinket. Just zip-tie any wires to the oval hole.

print_settings.Notes:: The full size prints do get some harmonic waves the taller it gets since it is suck thin walls.

title: Goblet, Grail, Chalice or ornate Vase
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This evolved out of a design I started in Onshape. I wanted a 'vase' type object of my own to print. Wanted a bit of detail. No overhangs to mess with the vase mode. And something to fill the volume of my Tronxy X3.

Full size is quite large 180mm x 202mm tall. Printed some at 33% and 0.08mm and 0.05mm layer height.

Grail_fine is designed to be printed in single wall vase mode and printed rather quickly.
Grail_cupped is solid with smooth inside.

Printer:

Tronxy X3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.05mm-0.24mm

Infill:

0%

Notes:

Be sure to scale to fit your printer's volume. Printed in vase mode. 3-5 base layers. No top layer. No infill.

Smaller white goblets were printed in PETG at 33% and with 0.05 or 0.08mm layer height. 0.05mm layer height took 3h4m to print.

The clearer ABScent one was printed at 33% and at 0.15mm and took 1h10m. Still want try an acetone vapor bath with this one.

Full size green PETG goblet took 4h36m ay 0.2mm layer height.

The full size prints do get some harmonic waves the taller it gets since it is suck thin walls.
Considered inverting and filling in the top and have the bottom open to make drum. Could make an interesting sound.

author: idig3d

description.text:
This micro timing belt coupler can be used to make timing belt loops instead of having to attach the timing belt to some sort of stationary bracket.

This one is so small that it can actually move all the way around the timing belt gear on the motor! Although the belt tends to slip a little bit whenever the couple is moving over the gears - unless you're using a larger gear.

It works out perfectly for my case because the coupler needs to move over one very large gear but not over the smaller one.

Print using 100% infill and it's also a good idea to super glue it into place AFTER sliding the timing belt into it.

If the single thread version is too small, try the double thread version.
